articles.headline: Economic Clouds? Wall Street Sees Signs of Sunshine
articles.snippet: Despite a drumbeat of bad economic news, the stock market is up, and for the first time in months, Wall Street analysts and executives sound upbeat.
articles.abstract: Despite a drumbeat of bad economic news, the stock market is up, and for the first time in months, Wall Street analysts and executives sound upbeat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Main Street may be struggling, but Wall Street is on a bit of a roll.

articles.headline: Stores Hint at Change Under New Castro
articles.snippet: President Raúl Castro’s tinkering may be tiny compared to Cuba’s problems, but he is still shaking up the country.
articles.abstract: President Raúl Castro’s tinkering may be tiny compared to Cuba’s problems, but he is still shaking up the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA  Can a rice maker possibly be revolutionary?

articles.headline: Clinton May Be Hopeful, but Obama Rolls On
articles.snippet: Barack Obama continues to pick up superdelegates, leaving his opponent with dwindling options.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama continues to pick up superdelegates, leaving his opponent with dwindling options.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS  Have Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s chances of winning the Democratic presidential nomination improved as Senator Barack Obama has struggled through his toughest month of this campaign?
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Democrats and Fox News Make Friends
articles.snippet: The once-frosty relationship between Fox News and the Democratic candidates seems to have grown warmer as they find each other useful.
articles.abstract: The once-frosty relationship between Fox News and the Democratic candidates seems to have grown warmer as they find each other useful.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standing in front of a television camera last week, the chairman of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign, Terry McAuliffe, uttered four words that the Fox News Channel would not soon forget.

articles.headline: A Pulpit-and-Pews Gulf on Obama’s Ex-Pastor
articles.snippet: Parishioners in North Carolina were not as sympathetic as black ministers to the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.
articles.abstract: Parishioners in North Carolina were not as sympathetic as black ministers to the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUMBERTON, N.C.  The Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., under fire for statements that have embarrassed Senator Barack Obama’s campaign, has found staunch support in the pulpits of black churches around North Carolina. The people in the pews, however, are far less accepting.

articles.headline: Beijing Air Terminal Goes All Out for the Games
articles.snippet: The $3.8 billion structure, the latest in China’s Olympic works, can handle more than 50 million fliers a year.
articles.abstract: The $3.8 billion structure, the latest in China’s Olympic works, can handle more than 50 million fliers a year.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Beijing airport’s new Terminal 3  twice the size of the Pentagon  is the largest building in the world.

articles.headline: Determining Who Rides the Lifeboat
articles.snippet: As the mortgage crisis spilled over into a credit squeeze threatening Wall Street, the government tried to prevent disaster while not helping those who don’t deserve it.
articles.abstract: As the mortgage crisis spilled over into a credit squeeze threatening Wall Street, the government tried to prevent disaster while not helping those who don’t deserve it.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I ask you, what am I? I’m one of the undeserving poor. That’s what I am. Think of what that means to a man. It means that he’s up agen middle class morality all the time ... I don’t need less than a deserving man; I need more. I don’t eat less hearty than him, and I drink a lot more.”

articles.headline: Exxon Posts Its 2nd-Best Quarter, but It’s Not Enough for Wall St.
articles.snippet: Exxon Mobil, the world’s largest publicly traded oil company, said its net income rose 17 percent in the first quarter, buoyed by high oil prices.
articles.abstract: Exxon Mobil, the world’s largest publicly traded oil company, said its net income rose 17 percent in the first quarter, buoyed by high oil prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil reported the second-best quarterly profit in its history on Thursday  and investors could barely hide their disappointment.

articles.headline: At Kodak, Some Old Things Are New Again
articles.snippet: Eastman Kodak, which once considered itself the Bell Labs of chemistry, has embraced the digital world and the researchers who understand it.
articles.abstract: Eastman Kodak, which once considered itself the Bell Labs of chemistry, has embraced the digital world and the researchers who understand it.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER  Steven J. Sasson, an electrical engineer who invented the first digital camera at Eastman Kodak in the 1970s, remembers well management’s dismay at his feat.

articles.headline: As Gas Costs Soar, Buyers Flock to Small Cars
articles.snippet: About one in five vehicles sold in the U.S. in April was a compact or subcompact car, while sales of pickups and S.U.V.’s fell sharply.
articles.abstract: About one in five vehicles sold in the U.S. in April was a compact or subcompact car, while sales of pickups and S.U.V.’s fell sharply.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Soaring gas prices have turned the steady migration by Americans to smaller cars into a stampede.
